mington at O'Clock in the afternoon, the following real

ing on the north side of Market street, and between


Broad and King Streets with small franc dwelling there
on occupied by Mrs. Bingham, and running through to
Shipley street. -


No. g. Adjoining MOL with two story brick dwelling,
with bake house and oven, in the cellar occupied by


thomas Johnson The lot about IS feet front on Ship
lev street. and running back the middle distance OF the
square.


No s. two story brick house with frame kitchen and
lot of ground containing three acres, bounded by Broad
street the old Ferry road lands of Joshua Woston, and
others This property has been occupied Brick Yard
for many years. and possesses every convenience for car
rying on the Brick making business upon large scae'
and Is at present occupied by David c. Wilson.

lands Of Esau Coke, John Morton and John Boser, with

Died. at the residence of Mrs Mary Corse, in Kent
County, Maryland, the first day OF November last, of
euce and fortude, Miss REBEKAH RASIN, aged sixty
nine years formerly resident of Wilmington, Del. where
she lived esteemed by all VINO had the pleasure Of her
quantance This most excellent female adorned her sa
ton in society; she firm believer in the doctrines of
the christian religion and devoted through life the
vice fher Kedeeer and the welfare and happiness of nu
meros relations and friends for whom she evncd the most
anxious socitude. As friend she affectona,e and
knd with gres, suav,y of united becoming
cheeruness ard gravity Her hand reMy to obey
the dictates of and generous hear in liberal con-
trbutonsand very many the blessings and that
|have followed her the tomb. But amongst her best


es none shone conspicuous than that deep innate
sentiment of piey which influenced her conduct during
long fe and in death enabled her to repose herself with
lust confidence upon the merits of her Redeemer Ihs
ldispensaton of an awsc Providence has made vacuum
in society easily repaired, and amongst her numerous


friends and relations who greatly bemoan their loss; and
long will the writer this small tribute cherish with live
y sentiments the memory Of the deceased
OEITUARY-Comn,uaicated.

We sometime since stated that, from personal
we were authorized to declare that great
changes in the public mind in this state taking
pIace in favor of the administration of the general
government. Proof this fact has been day after
day laid before the public. In the county of Schuyl-
xiii, at the last Presidential election, not a single
uote uas given for Mr. ya'anas and it would have
been difficult matter to nave found five men who
would have brayed the existing prejudice yopenly
declaring themselves in favor of Mr. Adams. In
this same county an administration meeting was
called to meet on the Oath ut. 1t appears to have
been general gathering together of the talent and
standing of the county. The honourable Judges Yost
and Raash, and Joseph Morgan, Esqs.. all prom-
nent supporters of the administration Of this state
were called to preside over the meeting. John Ban
nan, Mich'l Graeif. G. Leozer, Francis B. Nichols,
and w. B. Potts, Esqs., were appointed commit
tee to draft resolutions, &c.


The address and resolutions adopted. do great
honor to the meeting The sentiments expressed
in opposition to the elevation OF Gen. Jackson, are
of that firm serious, but dispassonate cast, which
show that deusion has yielded to the light of reason
and evidence, and that the work Of conviction is
thorough and well grounded.


The Legislature of PENNSYLVANIA met at Harris
burgh ON Tuesday last. MIR. MAHoN was chosen
Speaker of the Senate, and Mr.. MIDDLEswARTH
speaker Oh Inc F1ouSc ol NepIeseutdtNco' ~ '"
iority of AZ votes over VIM. McCREERy.


The Legislature of VIRGINIA met on Monday
last, at Richmond. Mr.. HoLr was reelected Spea.
ker of the Senate, and Mr.. BANKS Speaker OF the
House of Representatives, without opposition.


abundance of Doctors.-When we look abroad
over our beloved and thrice happy country, and see
every village blessed with from three to dozen
physicians, and every city crowded with from nifty
to five hundred Of these sons OF Escuaplus, we
should be apt to consider the Eastern salutatlon-
6 May you Hve thousand years,' II adopted N
these United States, as no longer mere compll
ment, but on the contrary, should be at loss To
conceive how it is possible to die short OF that Pc
riod, except, indeed, where one is shot direct,
through the head or through the heart, IN case
of honour'' -, :.

was fast approaching, when there should he no other

the Provincial Parliament to the 5rd Of January
the House having adhered to their choice Of Speaker
This is though be the beginning serious trouble.
We notice, in the Baltimore papers, Prospectus
of semi-wcelly Paper, to be published in the city
of Baltimore by E.. p Roberts, and edited by Ed-
WARD c. PINKNEY, and entitled The Marylander !;
which we have read with much pleasure. In its
politics, it maniess decided preference of the civ
il over the military candidate for the Presidency,
lustrious statesman, John Quincy Adams" Com
mercial, Agricultural, and Mechanical affairs, as
we'll as Bellies Lettres, &c. &c. will receive all suit
able attention. The Marylander is to be published
on Wednesday and Saturday, on an imperial sheet
at Four dollars per annnm, payable in advance, and
an extensive circulation is anticipated. The first
number appearedon Wednesday last


The Editors of the Miners Journal give an
count Of the steam works in operation in the Pea
cock mines, in the vicinity of Mount Carbon, and
remark that anthracite must and will be used to
generate steam in propeling boats, as much will be
saved by the use of coal.


English papers to the 3rd November have been
received at New-York


The course of Turkey, was not fully manifest,
though some supposed she would resist the media
ton of the Combined Powers, at all hazzards.


Spain continues in agitation-and there is still
some fighting between the rebels and the Kings
troops.


Steam Boat built in England for the Greeks had
been accidentally burnt in the Thames, and another
had foundered at sea.

At a large and respectable meeting If lie citizens o
Wilmington convened Al the Town HALL, al 3 o'cpck, ?
NJ Saturday the inst. pursuant to public Notice, io
the purpose uf forming IA Temperance socely, join
Bullock Jailed the Chair; and Robert Porter, chos
en- Secretary.


After which the meeting was addressed at considerable
length by Judge Hail. in which he took view Of the ex
tent Of the vice of ntempeance in this country ard the
means Which the temperate portion OF society possess
entirely to eradicate least very materially 70 crai
IFS baneful effects He then read to the Meeting form
of CONSTITUTIONS proposed for their government which
after being discussed, adopted and as folows
CONSTITUTION


Of the Temperance Society of Wilmington and 1T
vicinity.


Art !. This Society shall be denominated " The Tem
perance Sociey of Wilmington and its vicinity"


1t shall hold meeting on the Sd Monday of July every
year


Its officers shall be President, Vice Presidents
Corresponding Secretary, Recording Secretary Treas
and eight Directors. shall be the duty these Of
fcers meet the 4th Monday OF December, March,


June and September and they may hold occasional meet
ngs Any five of them shall constitute Board with pow
conduct all the concerns of the Society. They shall
each annual meeting lay before the society Report Of
its operations and concerns. .+


The officers shall be chosen Immediately this constu.
ton being established and at every annual meeting Of the
society Vacancies may be filled by the Board,


II The object this Society shall be osuppress intem-
perance.


Ill., The Members of this society believe that any use Of
sprituous liquors has tendency produce intempern
aud that no use these liquors can be considered safe
Otne temperance, Wncn dStreSSee the community there
rarely case hat has not arisen from what first
moderate and deemed prudent of arden spirits
he natural effect Of the of ardent spirits is to
come and destroy the very prudence, which, all admit
necessary to guard against the dangers arising from it.
Therefore the Members of this society regard SOL
emn duty to discountenance any of sprt liquors
and they hold themselves pledged to each other and to the
community, which they live abstain altogether from
the use ofsptuous liquors and not to suffer them in their
houses any establishments Of which they have the
trout excepting only the of these liquors medi
cine, when prescribed by physician.


Nv. This Society shall pond with Societies having
he object, in other paris Of the United States with
view to obtain all the information, which thus be &C.
quired to enable them more efecuay to promote their
object.


v. Each member shall annually pay to the Treasurer
cents fund to defrAy the expenses Of
and in dusng the information which shall deem proper
from time to time to lay before the public.


VI. Every person signing this Constitution shall be a
member of the Society, so long as he complies with the
fora uar1ic

ourlet to life but through the doors Of old age, to
such perfection would the art of healing arrive, and
Ia wiser man than Rush, (but not half 80 good one)
has told US that in the multitude Of counselcrs
there is safety. Ergo. to say, '..may you live
thousand years., is nothing more than saying SEM
lploy the doctors and pay them well.''


As to what is said Of young physician, going to
the Westward to look for an opening, and finding
those Of his profession grew thicker he advanced,
until at length seeing to doctors riding one horse,
The got discouraged and came home, it may be true
Ior not, we have seen nothing like it in New Eng
Hand. There are some, it is true, in this land OF
hills and health, who cannot get horse to ride, but
then it is not for the want OF horses, but Of money
to buy them.


We have made some estimate of the proportion Of
practising physicians, in New England. to the rest
of the inhabitants, and near as we can jump at the
truth, or we don't pretend to arrive at It slept by
stept,) we calculate the former, or curers to be as
to 500 of the latter or curees We believe the pro-
portion will not vary materially from this statement,
and when it is considered that 19-20ths OF the 600
get sick as seldom as possible, and still schooner
employ physician, it will be seen, that the doctor
has ample time to repair the health of the remainder,
and fit their constitutions for a thousand years
voyage and still be drawing out his bills to the re-
quisite longitude, or ia other words, making their
lengths in the inverse ratio Of the number OF pa
tients.-Berkshire american.


Shut the Door.-Among the greatest evils we are
doomed to suffer in this northern cmate, is that OF
being exposed to open doors-o keen blasts Of pt-
less winter day, through the carelessness OF those
who run in and out, as if for other purpose than
10 render well furnished room and good fire "null
and void.'


1t is rather idle project to think of warming call
out of doors," especially when the mercury is at 10
degrees below zero. And now that winter IS APP
preaching, beg leave to enoin upon all, to shut
he door! 1t is lesson that cannot be too early lncu-
Gated upon children to shut the door after them
The lesson should be given to hired people a.
bout the house. And this most important lesson
should not only be inculcated upon children and do
mestcs, but should be enforced, in such manner as
it may be best, even to chastisement of the former,
and when other means fail, to loss Of employment to
the latter. Possibly the method of Dean Swift might
be practised with advantage His hired girl, going
abroad enc day, left the door open and after pro-
ceedng couple of miles, was sent for by the Dean
to come back in great haste.-She obeyed the sum-
mons-and on returning, coolly ordered to shut
the door, She did So and forgot the lesson at
forwards. To conclnde, we say, 'Shut, shut the
door, good John" Betty, Molly, Peggy-master,
and mistress, man and maid, and daughter--get
this lesson by heart-nay, have it at your fingers
ends, and ever ready for applcaon--Shna the door.


Berk. american.

The British army in India consists at present of
100000 men--of which 100000 are mostly native
troops belonging to the East India Company. and
commanded by British oHicers--the remaining
o. 900 are kings troops, that the proportion be
tween the former and the latter'is only twelve to
one.

KENTUCKY ELEcTIoN.-We learn that Messrs.
CALHOUN and Chiffon have both resigned their
claims to the contested seat in Congress, under the
late election and have fairly agreed to refer the issue
to a new election, which the ernor Of the State
has no doubt, ordered to be he'd

We are sorrow to learn that Mr.. WEBSTER is
still detained in New York by the indispositlon both
of himself and Mrs. Webster-the consequence OF
much exposure on the journey from Boston during
the late severe weather.
GEORGE MCCLURE.
From, the National MteMgencer.

Since the above was written, Governor Giles has
again addressed the Legislature of Virgina-and
speaks of the destructive effects of the Tariff upon
aerculture--in opposition to various facts and evil
dence. On this part of his message, the Richmond
Wing remarks


10 this broad declaration, every buying and sell
ling man will oppose downright negative. Both
classes know, the that they never bought their
Goods 1.-THE otherthat they never able to sell
them cheaper. This single fact which every man.
personal experience in great measure confirms, is
worth volumes of defamation on the subject OF the
Tariff. In what sense does the Message mean,
that the Tariff has proved destructive ofagrcnlture?
We can put but two constructions upon it-elther
that il has enhanced the price of commodities Affect
ed by IT, to "a runous degree, that it has led to
realiatory measures in foreign Governments, dl-
rected against cur agricultural prosperity we de-
nv the assumption in both Senses Great Britain
has not attempted to counteract tariff by legis-
ation Her corn laws under which our bread stuffs
are prohibited except in contingencies, were ante
rior to our tariff or our independent existence, and
form system which she adopted to favor her agri-
cnltursts. not to annoy ours. VIII Gov. Giles pre-
tend that our tariff has excluded from foreign ports
single bushel of wheat, barrel Of -four, hogs
head of Tobacco that would have been otherwise adj
mtted Will he pretend, that If cur tariff we're
| layed Great Britnn would in consideration, more
freely admit our agricultural products He has paid
F little attention to the unwavering sehshness, and
monopolizng spirit of British policy, if he thinks
this If then, the Tariff has not ruinousy enhanc-
ed commodities, as every mans experience
tells him-fit has had no influence in excluding our
bread stulfs from British ports, as is obvous-in
what has it proved so destructive to the agrcultu
rist In nothing, save the unreal alarms of dema-
gogues--aarms that most people fortunately, begin
TO see are merely imaginary, # not in fact atogeth
er assumed to cover and advance some sinister po-
( tical purpose. For years, the tariff has been
hobby horse in Virginia--upon which various gen.
| temen have ridden into popular favor. Governor
Giles has mounted him, and believe it is the last
time, any political asprant will think it worth his
trouble to do so. We have seen the popular mind
undergo the most wonderful change on the subject
of manufactures, and expect to see that change
= in short time, universal and radical


Governor Shulze, of Pennsylvania, in his address
to the Legislature which met the 9Th inst. amongst
other things-sp with qualification, of the gen.
eral health, peace and plenty of the rapid ex-
tingnishment of the revolutionary and late war
debt, as well as that incurred by the purchase o
Louisiana and Florida of our exemption from
direct taxes at the moment we are thus discharglne
debts, and still having immense sums to devote te


internal improvement; Of the cause Of our presen


prosperity being attributable to wise course o
policy Of the strength of the Union consisting ii


the capacity of the several States to supply th


wants Of others and Of the maintenance of the re


lative rank and ability of Pennsylvania to upho


the Union, being inseparaby connected with anter


nal Improvement and american manufactures


Of the powers and duties Of Congress, on thes


subjects, the Governor thus expresses himself


differing, as will be seen, from their Exellencie


In Georgia, the Carolinas, and Virginia:


In regard, however, TO both of these great OF


jects there are duties belonging to the governmel


of the Union, and there are powers commensura'


with those duties, unquestionable IN their const


tutional existence they are beneficial in their OPP


ration, and Indispensable, to give the effect to tn


policy of the individual States.-They concern til


general welfare, and correspond with the nations


exigency. They are the concentrated energy


ALL applied under the guidance of all, to the commt


objects which transcend the powers, OF the abill'


of the particular States yet are necessary for tt


general government. To open, or to aid in oPeniI


those great lines of interior communication whic


promise extensive national benefits, in peace and


war; to protect American manufactures, and gi'


encouragement to domestic industry, by adequa


duties upon articles of foreign eompeton:-a


withinthose powers of Congress which have be'


fnvn nr,h1 dad ualpp


obvious as the bounds of our confidence are exten


ed hu the admission of new Stntes.

1t gives US great pleasure to lay before our read
ers, the following letter from Gen. GEO. MCCLURE,
to the Hon. RoBERT s. ROSE, on subject OF much
interest to the people Of the United States. We
regard the extract which it contains. of letter
from H. Clay, dated December 49, 1924 as trl-
umphant refutation OF the charges of corruption
preferred against him by Gen. Jackson, in relation
to the vote which he gave in the presidential eec
ton


Bath ST. Novenaber, 1927.
Hon. ROBERT s. RosE,


SIR: Your letter of the goth ult. was duly re-
ceved Your request that will transmit to you,
copy, extract of a certain letter which recev-
ed from Mr. Clay, in Dec 1924. on the subject of
the Presidential contest Nothing but regard for
the character Of Mr.. Clay induce me to comply with
your request, believing as do, that the charges
hbited against him by George Krener + Co. are
FALSE, and cannot be supported.
| After the electors of the President and Vice Pre-
slent were chosen in 1924, it was ascertained that
the election would come before the House of Repre-
sentatiyes and that Mr.. Clay would not be amongst
the number returned. Not knowing his sentiments
in relation to the candidates. addressed letter to
him. stating, that in all probability, the contest
would be confined to Mr.. Adams and Gen Jackson
and. in that case, wished to know which of them he
would prefer. Mr. Clay answered me promptly
BY letter, bearing date 28th Dec. 1874, of which
the following is ali extract.


81 have no hesitation IN saying. that nave lons
"since decided in favor of MIR. Adams, i'll case tht
"contest shoudb be between him and Gen. Jackson
"What, would ask, should be the distinguishing
:. characteristic ofan American Statesman Shoult
. s.itnot be devotion to civil liberty? Is it thel
IS compatible with that principle. to elect maj
" whose sole recommendation rests on military pre-
"tensions? | therefore say toyou unequyocally
"that | cannot consistent with my own principles
..support a. military man."


Yours, respectfully,
From the Geneva (N. ~ Chronicle.

following artlcie =


Europe-lmportant Private Intelligence.


The packet ship York brought letter to an
English gentleman in this city, from which we gath,
er important intelligence with respect to Greek and
Turkish affairs. This letter is from gentleman
in London, occupying responsible official station.


He states that there is an an express agreement
(not on understandings entered into by England
Russia and France, to conquer and partition the
Turkish dominions in Europe and Africa-Constan-
tnople and its dependencies are allotted to Russia
Egypt to England, and the isles of the Mediterra-
mean and some portions of the land ADJOINING tha'
con ia France. The Turk is'to be drove into ASIA
and the Greeks are to have IA government of their
own under the guaranty and protection of the Three
Powers


We are not at liberty. for obvious reasons, to
give names in regard to this information,--we can
only say that it comes from responsible source
through respectable medium

the speakerin the House. No business ofmoment
s'.', transacted on Wednesday and Tuesday last

RoBERr PORTER. Sec' c'etary.
i'ec. 8, 1877.

at Four dollars per annnm, payable in advance, and
an extensive circulation is anticipated. The first
number appearedon Wednesday last


The Editors of the Miners Journal give an
count Of the steam works in operation in the Pea
cock mines, in the vicinity of Mount Carbon, and
remark that anthracite must and will be used to
generate steam in propeling boats, as much will be
saved by the use of coal.


English papers to the 3rd November have been
received at New-York


The course of Turkey, was not fully manifest,
though some supposed she would resist the media
ton of the Combined Powers, at all hazzards.


Spain continues in agitation-and there is still
some fighting between the rebels and the Kings
troops.


Steam Boat built in England for the Greeks had
been accidentally burnt in the Thames, and another
had foundered at sea.

At a large and respectable meeting If lie citizens o
Wilmington convened Al the Town HALL, al 3 o'cpck, ?
NJ Saturday the inst. pursuant to public Notice, io
the purpose uf forming IA Temperance socely, join
Bullock Jailed the Chair; and Robert Porter, chos
en- Secretary.


After which the meeting was addressed at considerable
length by Judge Hail. in which he took view Of the ex
tent Of the vice of ntempeance in this country ard the
means Which the temperate portion OF society possess
entirely to eradicate least very materially 70 crai
IFS baneful effects He then read to the Meeting form
of CONSTITUTIONS proposed for their government which
after being discussed, adopted and as folows
CONSTITUTION


Of the Temperance Society of Wilmington and 1T
vicinity.


Art !. This Society shall be denominated " The Tem
perance Sociey of Wilmington and its vicinity"


1t shall hold meeting on the Sd Monday of July every
year


Its officers shall be President, Vice Presidents
Corresponding Secretary, Recording Secretary Treas
and eight Directors. shall be the duty these Of
fcers meet the 4th Monday OF December, March,


June and September and they may hold occasional meet
ngs Any five of them shall constitute Board with pow
conduct all the concerns of the Society. They shall
each annual meeting lay before the society Report Of
its operations and concerns. .+


The officers shall be chosen Immediately this constu.
ton being established and at every annual meeting Of the
society Vacancies may be filled by the Board,


II The object this Society shall be osuppress intem-
perance.


Ill., The Members of this society believe that any use Of
sprituous liquors has tendency produce intempern
aud that no use these liquors can be considered safe
Otne temperance, Wncn dStreSSee the community there
rarely case hat has not arisen from what first
moderate and deemed prudent of arden spirits
he natural effect Of the of ardent spirits is to
come and destroy the very prudence, which, all admit
necessary to guard against the dangers arising from it.
Therefore the Members of this society regard SOL
emn duty to discountenance any of sprt liquors
and they hold themselves pledged to each other and to the
community, which they live abstain altogether from
the use ofsptuous liquors and not to suffer them in their
houses any establishments Of which they have the
trout excepting only the of these liquors medi
cine, when prescribed by physician.


Nv. This Society shall pond with Societies having
he object, in other paris Of the United States with
view to obtain all the information, which thus be &C.
quired to enable them more efecuay to promote their
object.


v. Each member shall annually pay to the Treasurer
cents fund to defrAy the expenses Of
and in dusng the information which shall deem proper
from time to time to lay before the public.


VI. Every person signing this Constitution shall be a
member of the Society, so long as he complies with the
fora uar1ic

ourlet to life but through the doors Of old age, to
such perfection would the art of healing arrive, and
Ia wiser man than Rush, (but not half 80 good one)
has told US that in the multitude Of counselcrs
there is safety. Ergo. to say, '..may you live
thousand years., is nothing more than saying SEM
lploy the doctors and pay them well.''


As to what is said Of young physician, going to
the Westward to look for an opening, and finding
those Of his profession grew thicker he advanced,
until at length seeing to doctors riding one horse,
The got discouraged and came home, it may be true
Ior not, we have seen nothing like it in New Eng
Hand. There are some, it is true, in this land OF
hills and health, who cannot get horse to ride, but
then it is not for the want OF horses, but Of money
to buy them.


We have made some estimate of the proportion Of
practising physicians, in New England. to the rest
of the inhabitants, and near as we can jump at the
truth, or we don't pretend to arrive at It slept by
stept,) we calculate the former, or curers to be as
to 500 of the latter or curees We believe the pro-
portion will not vary materially from this statement,
and when it is considered that 19-20ths OF the 600
get sick as seldom as possible, and still schooner
employ physician, it will be seen, that the doctor
has ample time to repair the health of the remainder,
and fit their constitutions for a thousand years
voyage and still be drawing out his bills to the re-
quisite longitude, or ia other words, making their
lengths in the inverse ratio Of the number OF pa
tients.-Berkshire american.


Shut the Door.-Among the greatest evils we are
doomed to suffer in this northern cmate, is that OF
being exposed to open doors-o keen blasts Of pt-
less winter day, through the carelessness OF those
who run in and out, as if for other purpose than
10 render well furnished room and good fire "null
and void.'


1t is rather idle project to think of warming call
out of doors," especially when the mercury is at 10
degrees below zero. And now that winter IS APP
preaching, beg leave to enoin upon all, to shut
he door! 1t is lesson that cannot be too early lncu-
Gated upon children to shut the door after them
The lesson should be given to hired people a.
bout the house. And this most important lesson
should not only be inculcated upon children and do
mestcs, but should be enforced, in such manner as
it may be best, even to chastisement of the former,
and when other means fail, to loss Of employment to
the latter. Possibly the method of Dean Swift might
be practised with advantage His hired girl, going
abroad enc day, left the door open and after pro-
ceedng couple of miles, was sent for by the Dean
to come back in great haste.-She obeyed the sum-
mons-and on returning, coolly ordered to shut
the door, She did So and forgot the lesson at
forwards. To conclnde, we say, 'Shut, shut the
door, good John" Betty, Molly, Peggy-master,
and mistress, man and maid, and daughter--get
this lesson by heart-nay, have it at your fingers
ends, and ever ready for applcaon--Shna the door.


Berk. american.

The British army in India consists at present of
100000 men--of which 100000 are mostly native
troops belonging to the East India Company. and
commanded by British oHicers--the remaining
o. 900 are kings troops, that the proportion be
tween the former and the latter'is only twelve to
one.

KENTUCKY ELEcTIoN.-We learn that Messrs.
CALHOUN and Chiffon have both resigned their
claims to the contested seat in Congress, under the
late election and have fairly agreed to refer the issue
to a new election, which the ernor Of the State
has no doubt, ordered to be he'd

GEORGE MCCLURE.

From, the National MteMgencer.
full articles.article:
We are sorrow to learn that Mr.. WEBSTER is
still detained in New York by the indispositlon both
of himself and Mrs. Webster-the consequence OF
much exposure on the journey from Boston during
the late severe weather.

Since the above was written, Governor Giles has
again addressed the Legislature of Virgina-and
speaks of the destructive effects of the Tariff upon
aerculture--in opposition to various facts and evil
dence. On this part of his message, the Richmond
Wing remarks


10 this broad declaration, every buying and sell
ling man will oppose downright negative. Both
classes know, the that they never bought their
Goods 1.-THE otherthat they never able to sell
them cheaper. This single fact which every man.
personal experience in great measure confirms, is
worth volumes of defamation on the subject OF the
Tariff. In what sense does the Message mean,
that the Tariff has proved destructive ofagrcnlture?
We can put but two constructions upon it-elther
that il has enhanced the price of commodities Affect
ed by IT, to "a runous degree, that it has led to
realiatory measures in foreign Governments, dl-
rected against cur agricultural prosperity we de-
nv the assumption in both Senses Great Britain
has not attempted to counteract tariff by legis-
ation Her corn laws under which our bread stuffs
are prohibited except in contingencies, were ante
rior to our tariff or our independent existence, and
form system which she adopted to favor her agri-
cnltursts. not to annoy ours. VIII Gov. Giles pre-
tend that our tariff has excluded from foreign ports
single bushel of wheat, barrel Of -four, hogs
head of Tobacco that would have been otherwise adj
mtted Will he pretend, that If cur tariff we're
| layed Great Britnn would in consideration, more
freely admit our agricultural products He has paid
F little attention to the unwavering sehshness, and
monopolizng spirit of British policy, if he thinks
this If then, the Tariff has not ruinousy enhanc-
ed commodities, as every mans experience
tells him-fit has had no influence in excluding our
bread stulfs from British ports, as is obvous-in
what has it proved so destructive to the agrcultu
rist In nothing, save the unreal alarms of dema-
gogues--aarms that most people fortunately, begin
TO see are merely imaginary, # not in fact atogeth
er assumed to cover and advance some sinister po-
( tical purpose. For years, the tariff has been
hobby horse in Virginia--upon which various gen.
| temen have ridden into popular favor. Governor
Giles has mounted him, and believe it is the last
time, any political asprant will think it worth his
trouble to do so. We have seen the popular mind
undergo the most wonderful change on the subject
of manufactures, and expect to see that change
= in short time, universal and radical


Governor Shulze, of Pennsylvania, in his address

direct taxes at the moment we are thus discharglne

internal improvement; Of the cause Of our presen


prosperity being attributable to wise course o
policy Of the strength of the Union consisting ii


the capacity of the several States to supply th


wants Of others and Of the maintenance of the re


lative rank and ability of Pennsylvania to upho


the Union, being inseparaby connected with anter


nal Improvement and american manufactures


Of the powers and duties Of Congress, on thes


subjects, the Governor thus expresses himself


differing, as will be seen, from their Exellencie


In Georgia, the Carolinas, and Virginia:


In regard, however, TO both of these great OF


jects there are duties belonging to the governmel


of the Union, and there are powers commensura'


with those duties, unquestionable IN their const


tutional existence they are beneficial in their OPP


ration, and Indispensable, to give the effect to tn


policy of the individual States.-They concern til


general welfare, and correspond with the nations


exigency. They are the concentrated energy


ALL applied under the guidance of all, to the commt


objects which transcend the powers, OF the abill'


of the particular States yet are necessary for tt


general government. To open, or to aid in oPeniI


those great lines of interior communication whic


promise extensive national benefits, in peace and


war; to protect American manufactures, and gi'


encouragement to domestic industry, by adequa

full articles.headline: From the Geneva (N. ~ Chronicle.
full articles.article:
1t gives US great pleasure to lay before our read
ers, the following letter from Gen. GEO. MCCLURE,
to the Hon. RoBERT s. ROSE, on subject OF much
interest to the people Of the United States. We
regard the extract which it contains. of letter
from H. Clay, dated December 49, 1924 as trl-
umphant refutation OF the charges of corruption
preferred against him by Gen. Jackson, in relation
to the vote which he gave in the presidential eec
ton


Bath ST. Novenaber, 1927.
Hon. ROBERT s. RosE,


SIR: Your letter of the goth ult. was duly re-
ceved Your request that will transmit to you,
copy, extract of a certain letter which recev-
ed from Mr. Clay, in Dec 1924. on the subject of
the Presidential contest Nothing but regard for
the character Of Mr.. Clay induce me to comply with
your request, believing as do, that the charges
hbited against him by George Krener + Co. are
FALSE, and cannot be supported.
| After the electors of the President and Vice Pre-
slent were chosen in 1924, it was ascertained that
the election would come before the House of Repre-
sentatiyes and that Mr.. Clay would not be amongst
the number returned. Not knowing his sentiments
in relation to the candidates. addressed letter to
him. stating, that in all probability, the contest
would be confined to Mr.. Adams and Gen Jackson
and. in that case, wished to know which of them he
would prefer. Mr. Clay answered me promptly
BY letter, bearing date 28th Dec. 1874, of which
the following is ali extract.


81 have no hesitation IN saying. that nave lons
"since decided in favor of MIR. Adams, i'll case tht
"contest shoudb be between him and Gen. Jackson
"What, would ask, should be the distinguishing
:. characteristic ofan American Statesman Shoult
. s.itnot be devotion to civil liberty? Is it thel
IS compatible with that principle. to elect maj
" whose sole recommendation rests on military pre-
"tensions? | therefore say toyou unequyocally
"that | cannot consistent with my own principles
..support a. military man."


Yours, respectfully,

full articles.headline:
The New-York Morning Courier contains the
following article -
full articles.article:
following artlcie =


Europe-lmportant Private Intelligence.


The packet ship York brought letter to an
English gentleman in this city, from which we gath,
er important intelligence with respect to Greek and
Turkish affairs. This letter is from gentleman
in London, occupying responsible official station.


He states that there is an an express agreement
(not on understandings entered into by England
Russia and France, to conquer and partition the
Turkish dominions in Europe and Africa-Constan-
tnople and its dependencies are allotted to Russia
Egypt to England, and the isles of the Mediterra-
mean and some portions of the land ADJOINING tha'
con ia France. The Turk is'to be drove into ASIA
and the Greeks are to have IA government of their
own under the guaranty and protection of the Three
Powers


We are not at liberty. for obvious reasons, to
give names in regard to this information,--we can
only say that it comes from responsible source
through respectable medium

Both Houses of Congress adjourned from We'd
nesday to Monday, when the Committees would be
chosen. by ballot in the senatc--and appointed by
the speakerin the House. No business ofmoment
s'.', transacted on Wednesday and Tuesday last
